_exec_summary.SummaryText:
A. EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

[40 CFR 68.155; CalARP Article 3, 2745.3]

The Risk Management Program at Uni-Kool Partners is designed to prevent the occurrence and

minimize the consequences of releases of anhydrous ammonia from the refrigeration process.

The following is a summary of the programs, policies, and procedures in place to reduce the risk

of a hazardous materials release.

The purpose of the RMP is threefold: 1.) to prevent unwanted releases of hazardous chemicals,

especially into locations that could expose employees and others to serious hazards, 2.) to

identify hazards associated with the use of anhydrous ammonia, and 3.) to provide procedures

to minimize the risks involved with handling this material.

Uni-Kool Partners has implemented the RMP at the Salinas, CA facility in order to comply with

regulations, and to fulfill this facility's responsibility to protect its employees, equipment,

property, the surrounding community, and the environment from accidental releases of

anhydrous ammonia.

1. Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy

Uni-Kool Partners will maintain a release prevention program to eliminate or minimize any

releases. The program will include regular inspections, monitoring equipment and logging

conditions, scheduled maintenance, and operator training. There is a program to analyze

releases for ways to prevent a similar future release, see Incident Investigation Forms. A Risk

Management Program, which includes accident prevention procedures for the ammonia

refrigeration system, is maintained on-site along with this RMP.

The ammonia refrigeration system has specific safety procedures to prevent a release.

Operators and mechanics are trained for safe operation and maintenance of the refrigeration

system. They are also trained in emergency response procedures in the event of an ammonia

release. There are emergency shut off switches for shutting down the system. Personnel will

automatically be notified if any detector e

xceeds set point. Monitoring is 24 hours a day. An

emergency control box and diffusion tank allows system pressure to be relieved manually. All

relief valves for the fixed equipment at W. Market are tied to the ammonia diffusion tank to

prevent high pressure releases to ambient.

Onsite personnel provide initial emergency response. Onsite personnel will make a preliminary

assessment in the event of a release and will provide first response. First response may include

emergency equipment shutdown, system isolation, or controlled operation such as pump down

to prevent or reduce an offsite release with full face cartridge mask. First response does not

include wearing a self-contained breathing apparatus and entry into the area where leak occurs.

Uni-Kool personnel are not certified to perform this type of safety response.

No emergency operations will be performed that are beyond the

capabilities of the operators or other onsite personnel.

Risk Management Plan with Process Safety Management November, 2015

Uni-Kool Partners II-2

Salinas, CA

Local fire and police departments with mutual aid response will provide emergency response for

a major release event. The refrigeration contractors would also be on-call to provide emergency

response.

Emergency response training will be conducted yearly for current employees and as required for

new employees. Records will be kept of all training performed at the site for a minimum of five

(5) years.

2. Description of Stationary Source and Substance Handled

Uni-Kool Partners, located at West Market St. Facilities, Salinas, CA, utilizes anhydrous

ammonia as a refrigerant in their operations. The facility was constructed under applicable

codes and industry standards at the time of construction.

This facility utilizes anhydrous ammonia as a refrigerant in their vacuum cooling, produce

cooling, and ice making operations as well as cold storage prior to shipment. Fresh product is

brought from the fields and cooled

to remove field heat. The produce is then packaged and

stored in a cold storage warehouse prior to shipment form the refrigerated docks. Ammonia is

the only listed material used at this facility. The plant operates with a total charge of

approximately 44,805 lbs. of ammonia distributed throughout the West Market St. facilities and

equipment. The refrigeration systems for each facility are independent of one another. The

largest single system charge is 13,905 lbs. at 730 West Market St. facility.

The Uni-Kool Partners West Market St. Facilities have both fixed and portable refrigeration

systems onsite composed of compressors with common thermosiphon receivers, evaporative

condensers, vacuum tubes, evaporative cooling coils, pressure vessels, ammonia pumps, water

chillers, ice generators and a diffusion tank. All compressors have safety switches that would

shut down the compressors upon detection of unsafe operating conditions. Pressure vessels,

with the exception of some oil separators, and the compressors are protected by safety relief

valves against high pressure situations. There are ammonia detectors in most of the cold rooms

and in the mechanical room/areas for alarming. There is a list of responders experienced with

ammonia refrigeration that would respond and determine specific responses for any incident.

Safeties and detection equipment are tested and maintained by experienced maintenance

personnel as spelled out in the SOPs (Standard Operating Procedures) and testing and

inspection

The refrigeration systems at this facility are single stage vapor compression cycles. In general,

the process chemistry for single-stage systems is shown in Section IV.

The refrigeration systems consist of the following equipment:

? Reciprocating and screw compressors,

? Low pressure receivers,

? High pressure receivers,

? Evaporative cooling condensers,

? Air cooling evaporators,

? Freeze evaporators,

? Ammonia diffusion tanks

? Ammonia pumps,

? Water

pumps,

? Water chillers,

Risk Management Plan with Process Safety Management November, 2015

Uni-Kool Partners II-3

Salinas, CA

? Ammonia purgers,

? Pressure coolers,

? Suction traps (knockout drums),

? Liquid subcooler,

? Oil separators,

? Oil coolers,

? Electric controls

? A refrigeration control panel, and

? An emergency electric switch.

The Ammonia Refrigeration Safety Inspection (IIAR) Checklists, located in Appendix A,

describe equipment details. A complete set of system drawings is in Appendix B. Included in

this section are the equipment layout and process and instrumentation diagrams (P&IDs).

The substance handled at Uni-Kool Partners, anhydrous ammonia (NH3), is a gas in its natural

state and is extremely irritating to mucous membranes and lung tissue. The gas is pungent and

may cause suffocation, as shortness of breath and labored breathing can develop if inhaled.

Prolonged inhalation of high concentrations may cause bronchitis and/or pneumonia, with some

residual reduction in pulmonary functions. Repeated or prolonged contact of high

concentrations of ammonia to the skin can cause frostbite, redness, pain, and serious skin burn.

A Globally Harmonized System for Classification and Labelling Chemicals (GHS) Safety Data

sheet for ammonia is included in Appendix C. Written in both Spanish and English, the GHS

data sheet details the chemical properties and health hazards of anhydrous ammonia.

3. Accidental Release Prevention Program

Uni-Kool Partners maintains an accidental release prevention program designed to eliminate or

minimize ammonia releases. The program includes equipment monitoring, regular inspections

and maintenance, and log keeping of operating conditions, scheduled maintenance, emergency

response, and operator training.

The ammonia refrigeration system has specific safety measures in place to prevent accidental

release. Operators and mechanics are trained for safe operation and maintenance of the

refrigeration s

ystem. They are also trained in emergency response procedures in the event of an

ammonia release. An alarm and detection system monitors the facility for unsafe ammonia

concentration levels and for operating conditions outside of safety set points. Monitoring is

done 24 hours per day. Relief valves are installed to protect both the high and low sides from an

overpressure situation. Relief valves are currently piped to a diffusion tank which provides a

system-wide mitigation measure. Compressors have control panels, which will automatically

shut down the compressors if pressure and temperature set points are exceeded. An emergency

control box allows system pressures to be relieved without releasing to the ambient. Additional

information about the ammonia detection system, the sensor locations and accompanying

equipment specifications sheets can be found in Appendix P.

4. Process Hazard Analysis

A thorough review of the system including a "What If" Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) was

performed for this facility on July 29 & Aug 4, 2015 and is included in Appendix D. Prior to

startup, an engineering walkthrough was performed that included a thorough review of the

refrigeration equipment and safety systems. In addition to visual inspections, code compliance

reviews were performed. These reports are included in Seismic Review and Code and

Risk Management Plan with Process Safety Management November, 2015

Uni-Kool Partners II-4

Salinas, CA

Compliance Audits. Recommendations for follow-up were made on the basis of criticality to the

safe and efficient operation of the system. Equipment corrections and updates were made for

those items determined to have the highest potential for offsite releases.

5. Training

Safety and equipment operational training will be conducted on a yearly basis and includes

equipment operational procedures, emergency response procedures, review of Risk Management

Plan procedures, Hazardous Materials Business Plan procedures, a

nd evacuation procedures.

Additional items requiring further review, correction, and/or updating are identified and

presented at tailgate meetings. Training documentation and forms are included in Appendix E.

6. Updates

As required in Section VI, Updates, refrigeration equipment will be inspected and reviewed

periodically and as new equipment becomes operational onsite. When a significant change

occurs, the RMP shall be updated to reflect the change. Any management changes must also be

updated. This RMP, which includes accident prevention procedures for the ammonia

refrigeration system, is maintained onsite, and is also submitted electronically to the EPA

Central Data Exchange (CDX). A copy of the most recent registration is included in Appendix I

7. Five-Year Accident History

According to Uni-Kool Partners personnel, in the past five years there have been no releases of

anhydrous ammonia resulting in reportable quantities or injuries. Releases of ammonia, should

they occur, will be responded to in accordance with company policy and the procedures outlined

in this RMP.

8. Emergency Response Program

The facility has implemented the State and County mandated emergency response plan

(Business Response Plan). This plan outlines procedures for emergency ammonia release

response, as well as general facility response, see Appendix L for the program.

In event of a release, certain personnel are designated to determine the potential hazard and

coordinate response procedures. The emergency coordinator is responsible for contacting

emergency response agencies, schools, daycare centers, and acute care facilities that may be

affected by the release. The coordinator will also be responsible for evacuation of employees if

necessary and for coordination with community emergency responders if offsite evacuations are

required.

The emergency response program consists of the following elements:

? Contact phone numbers for emergency coordinator and emergency co

ntacts

? Notification procedures

? Hazardous material incident response to ammonia releases and other incidents

? Coordinator and personnel responsibilities

? Releases to be reported

? Evacuation plans

? Emergency response checklist

? Emergency shutdown procedures

? Emergency response training

Risk Management Plan with Process Safety Management November, 2015

Uni-Kool Partners II-5

Salinas, CA

See Section V and Appendix L for additional information about the program.

9. Planned Changes to Improve System Safety

Additional risk reduction measures may be implemented to further reduce the potential for an

accidental release. These measures may include installation of upgraded piping and equipment

supports, installation of equipment labeling, and implementation of a program aimed

specifically at the maintenance, training, and emergency response procedures for the ammonia

based refrigeration equipment.
